article.title: Active plasmon injection scheme for subdiffraction imaging with imperfect negative index flat lens

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the "Compensated Image" in Figure 1 represent?
choices: The original object after being passed through a conventional lens.
The image of the original object obtained without any loss compensation.
The image of the original object after applying a passive inverse filter to compensate for losses in the NIFL.
The image of the original object after applying active loss compensation using an external auxiliary source.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 2 shows the Fourier spectra of different components. What is the significance of the noise observed at high spatial frequencies in the "Compensated Image" spectrum?
choices: It represents the intrinsic noise of the original object.
It arises due to imperfections in the fabrication of the NIFL.
It is amplified by the inverse filter used for loss compensation.
It is a result of interference from external electromagnetic sources.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 3 depicts an object with four Gaussian features. What is the main reason for the poor resolution in the "Compensated Image" compared to the three-Gaussian object in Figure 1?
choices: The four-Gaussian object has a higher spatial frequency content that is more susceptible to noise.
The NIFL used in Figure 3 has a higher degree of material loss.
The passive inverse filter is not powerful enough to compensate for the increased complexity of the object.
The four-Gaussian object is illuminated with a lower intensity, leading to a lower signal-to-noise ratio.

multiple_choice_question.text: In Figure 4, the Fourier spectrum of the four-Gaussian object reveals a feature at ky/k0 = 2 that is buried under noise. What is the main limitation this poses for the passive compensation scheme?
choices: It prevents accurate determination of the object\'s spatial frequency content.
It hinders the ability to effectively compensate for material losses at that specific spatial frequency.
It introduces significant distortions in the reconstructed image, making it unrecognizable.
It necessitates the use of complex and computationally expensive algorithms for noise reduction.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 5 illustrates the geometry used for numerical simulations of the NIFL. What is the purpose of the Perfectly Matched Layer (PML) surrounding the simulation domain?
choices: To mimic the behavior of a perfect lens with no material losses.
To prevent reflections at the boundaries of the simulation domain, ensuring accurate calculation of the fields.
To introduce controlled noise into the system, allowing for realistic simulations.
To amplify the evanescent waves, improving the resolution of the imaging system.
